description: Circuit unoptimization transforms a quantum circuit into a different circuit that uses more gate operations while maintaining the same unitary transformation. Unlike folding (which inserts G G† pairs), unoptimization produces structurally different circuits through gate insertion, swapping, decomposition, and resynthesis.

The key advantage is that unoptimization generates exponentially many distinct circuit variants at each noise level. Averaging over these variants reduces bias from coherent errors and biased noise sources on quantum processors.

Another practical benefit is that unoptimized circuits resist server-side compiler optimization. Transpilers cannot easily simplify the expanded sequences back to the original, making ZNE viable even when optimization cannot be disabled.
how_it_works: Start with the original compiled circuit C with gate count n(C).
Apply the four-step iterative unoptimization recipe:
(1) INSERT: Add a random two-qubit unitary A and its conjugate A† between two existing two-qubit gates B₁ and B₂ that share a qubit.
(2) SWAP: Exchange B₁ with A†, creating a modified gate via conjugation.
(3) DECOMPOSE: Break the resulting multi-qubit unitaries into elementary gates.
(4) SYNTHESIZE: Apply circuit synthesis/optimization passes to reduce overhead while preserving the increased gate count.
Repeat the procedure i times to produce unoptimized circuit Rᵢ(C) with increased gate count.
The noise scale factor is λᵢ = n(Rᵢ(C)) / n(C), where n denotes total gate count.
Execute circuits at multiple noise levels and extrapolate to zero noise.
advantages: Generates exponentially many structurally distinct circuit variants at each noise level
Enables noise averaging over circuit variants to reduce coherent error bias
Resists server-side compiler simplification—transpilers cannot easily undo the expansion
Enables fractional noise scaling factors near λ = 1
disadvantages: More complex to implement than simple folding
Circuit structure changes significantly at each noise level
May increase circuit depth substantially for large scale factors
Requires careful implementation of the insert-swap-decompose-synthesize procedure
use_cases: ZNE on cloud quantum computers where server-side optimization cannot be disabled
Mitigating coherent errors through variant averaging
Situations requiring fine-grained fractional scale factors
QAOA and quantum volume circuits (demonstrated in the original paper)
